Mac OS X "Full Keyboard Access" refers to setting Keyboard→Shortcuts→Full Keyboard Access to "All controls" in the System Preferences.
Magnetometer
Makes the form control non-editable. Unlike the disabled attribute, readonly form controls are still included in form submissions and the user can still select (but not edit) their value text.
Many browsers support the crypto.getRandomValues() method, but not actual cryptography functionality under crypto.subtle.
Matches elements based on their directionality. :dir(ltr) matches elements which are Left-to-Right. :dir(rtl) matches elements which are Right-to-Left.
MathML
MathML demos
MathML torture test
Matrix
Media Capture from DOM Elements API
Media Capture functionality in Microsoft Edge
Media Fragments
Media Queries
Media Queries tutorial
Media Queries: interaction media features
Media Queries: resolution feature
Media Source Extensions
Media fragments on MDN
MediaRecorder API
MediaSource demo
Meta programming with ECMAScript 6 proxies
Meta tag to define a suggested color that browsers should use to customize the display of the page or of the surrounding user interface.
Method for data binding, a now-withdrawn ECMAScript 7 proposal
Method for having two-way communication between browsing contexts (using MessageChannel)
Method for observing and reacting to changes to sizes of DOM elements.
Method for observing and reacting to changes to the DOM. Replaces MutationEvents, which is deprecated.
Method of accessing DOM elements by class name
Method of accessing DOM elements using CSS selectors
Method of accessing external device data (such as a webcam video stream). Formerly this was envisioned as the <device> element.
Method of adding pronunciation or other annotations using ruby elements (primarily used in East Asian typography).
Method of adjusting the font size in a matter that relates to the height of lowercase vs. uppercase letters. This makes it easier to set the size of fallback fonts.
Method of alerting the user outside of a web page by displaying notifications (that do not require interaction by the user).

Method of allowing a webpage to handle a given protocol using navigator.registerProtocolHandler. This allows certain URLs to be opened by a given web application, for example mailto: addresses can be opened by a webmail client.
Method of allowing an element to be resized by the user, with options to limit to a given direction.
Method of allowing calculated values for length units, i.e. width: calc(100% - 3em)
Method of allowing multiple scripts to communicate with a single web worker.
Method of allowing two users to communicate directly, browser to browser using the RTCPeerConnection API.
Method of applying advanced typographic and language-specific font features to supported OpenType fonts.
Method of applying and accessing custom data to elements.
Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale or hue) to content/elements below the target element.
Method of applying filter effects (like blur, grayscale, brightness, contrast and hue) to elements, previously only possible by using SVG.
Method of applying one or more shadow or blur effects to text
Method of applying styles based on media information. Includes things like page and device dimensions
Method of continuously sending data from a server to the browser, rather than repeatedly requesting it (EventSource interface, used to fall under HTML5)
Method of controlling number values in generated content, using the counter-reset and counter-increment properties.
Method of controlling when words at the end of lines should be hyphenated using the "hyphens" property.
Method of converting JavaScript objects to JSON strings and JSON back to objects using JSON.stringify() and JSON.parse()
Method of creating URL handles to the specified File or Blob object.
Method of creating an enlarged cap, including a drop or raised cap, in a robust way.
Method of creating, composing, and consuming streams of data, that map efficiently to low-level I/O primitives, and allow easy composition with built-in backpressure and queuing.
Method of customizing the width of the tab character. Only effective using 'white-space: pre' or 'white-space: pre-wrap'.
Method of declaring a portion of reusable markup that is parsed but not rendered until cloned.
Method of declaring the outline (stroke) width and color for text.
Method of defining a conical or repeating conical color gradient as a CSS image.
Method of defining a context menu item, now deprecated and removed from the HTML specification.
Method of defining a linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.
Method of defining a repeating linear or radial color gradient as a CSS image.
Method of defining how a background image is attached to a scrollable element. Values include scroll (default), fixed and local.
Method of defining new HTML tags.
Method of defining the effect resulting from overlaying two layers on a Canvas element.

Method of defining the type, style and color of lines in the text-decoration property. These can be defined as shorthand (e.g. text-decoration: line-through dashed blue) or as single properties (e.g. text-decoration-color: blue)
Method of defining the visible region of an HTML element using SVG or a shape definition.
Method of describing colors using Hue, Saturation and Lightness (hsl()) rather than just RGB, as well as allowing alpha-transparency with rgba() and hsla().
Method of displaying SVG images in HTML using <img>.
Method of displaying a reflection of an element
Method of displaying an element as a block while flowing it with text.
Method of displaying an inner or outer shadow effect to elements
Method of displaying basic Vector Graphics features using the embed or object elements. Refers to the SVG 1.1 spec.
Method of displaying elements as tables, rows, and cells. Includes support for all display: table-* properties as well as display: inline-table
Method of displaying fonts downloaded from websites
Method of displaying only a part of an SVG image by defining a view ID or view box dimensions as the file's fragment identifier.
Method of displaying part of an element, using a selected image as a mask
Method of displaying text on Canvas elements

Method of displaying text or images before or after the given element's contents using the ::before and ::after pseudo-elements. All browsers with support also support the attr() notation in the content property.
Method of easily creating custom dialog boxes to display to the user with modal or non-modal options. Also includes a ::backdrop pseudo-element for behind the element.
Method of easily dragging and dropping elements on a page, requiring minimal JavaScript.
Method of easily manipulating classes on elements, using the DOMTokenList object.
Method of easily manipulating rel attribute values on elements, using the DOMTokenList object (similar to classList).
Method of embedding images and other files in webpages as a string of text, generally using base64 encoding.

Method of establishing and maintaining functional boundaries between DOM trees and how these trees interact with each other within a document, thus enabling better functional encapsulation within the DOM & CSS.

Method of establishing and maintaining functional boundaries between DOM trees and how these trees interact with each other within a document, thus enabling better functional encapsulation within the DOM.
Method of flowing content into multiple elements.
Method of flowing information in multiple columns
Method of generating cryptographically random values.
Method of generating dynamic 3D graphics using JavaScript, accelerated through hardware
Method of generating fast, dynamic graphics using JavaScript.
Method of including and reusing HTML documents in other HTML documents.
Method of indicating a progress state.
Method of indicating the current level of a gauge.
Method of informing a website of the user's geographical location
Method of keeping an element in a fixed location regardless of scroll position
Method of letting the browser pick the most appropriate CSS background image from a given set, primarily for high PPI screens.
Method of making any HTML element editable.
Method of making the border corners round. Covers support for the shorthand border-radius as well as the long-hand properties (e.g. border-top-left-radius)
Method of manipulating file objects in web applications client-side, as well as programmatically selecting them and accessing their data.
Method of manipulating the user's browser's session history in JavaScript using history.pushState, history.replaceState and the popstate event.
Method of optimizing animations by informing the browser which elements will change and what properties will change.
Method of outputting data to the browser's console, intended for development purposes.
Method of performing XMLHttpRequests across domains
Method of placing code in a "strict" operating context.

Method of playing sound on webpages (without requiring a plug-in). Includes support for the following media properties: currentSrc, currentTime, paused, playbackRate, buffered, duration, played, seekable, ended, autoplay, loop, controls, volume & muted

Method of playing videos on webpages (without requiring a plug-in). Includes support for the following media properties: currentSrc, currentTime, paused, playbackRate, buffered, duration, played, seekable, ended, autoplay, loop, controls, volume & muted

Method of positioning elements in horizontal or vertical stacks. Support includes all properties prefixed with flex, as well as display: flex, display: inline-flex, align-content, align-items, align-self, justify-content and order.
Method of preventing text/element selection using CSS.
Method of providing ways for people with disabilities to use dynamic web content and web applications.
Method of reading and writing files to a sandboxed file system.
Method of reading the contents of a File or Blob object into memory
Method of registering when, where and how the interface is touched, for devices with a touch screen. These DOM events are similar to mousedown, mousemove, etc.
Method of running external site pages with reduced privileges (e.g. no JavaScript) in iframes.
Method of running scripts in the background, isolated from the web page
Method of sending information from a page on one domain to a page on a different one (using postMessage)
Method of setting a list of options for a user to select in a text field, while leaving the ability to enter a custom value.
Method of setting a minimum or maximum width or height to an element.
Method of setting placeholder text for text-like input fields, to suggest the expected inserted information.

Method of setting required fields and field types without requiring JavaScript. This includes preventing forms from being submitted when appropriate, the checkValidity() method as well as support for the :invalid, :valid, and :required CSS pseudo-classes.
Method of setting the transparency level of an element
Method of specifying and selecting between multiple audio tracks. Useful for providing audio descriptions, director's commentary, additional languages, alternative takes, etc.
Method of specifying and selecting between multiple video tracks. Useful for providing sign language tracks, burnt-in captions or subtitles, alternative camera angles, etc.

Method of specifying how an object (image or video) should fit inside its box. object-fit options include "contain" (fit according to aspect ratio), "fill" (stretches object to fill) and "cover" (overflows box but maintains ratio), where object-position allows the object to be repositioned like background-image does.
Method of specifying the scrolling behavior for a scrolling box, when scrolling happens due to navigation or CSSOM scrolling APIs.
Method of specifying whether or not an element's borders and padding should be included in size units
Method of storing data client-side, allows SQLite database queries for access and manipulation
Method of storing data client-side, allows indexed database queries.
Method of storing data locally like cookies, but for larger amounts of data (sessionStorage and localStorage, used to fall under HTML5).
Method of testing whether or not a DOM element matches a given selector. Formerly known (and largely supported with prefix) as matchesSelector.

Method of transforming an element in the third dimension using the transform property. Includes support for the perspective property to set the perspective in z-space and the backface-visibility property to toggle display of the reverse side of a 3D-transformed element.
Method of transforming an element including rotating, scaling, etc. Includes support for transform as well as transform-origin properties.
Method of using HTML5 Canvas as a background image. Not currently part of any specification.
Method of using Photoshop-like effects on SVG objects including blurring and color manipulation.
Method of using SMIL animation in web pages
Method of using SVG images as CSS backgrounds
Method of using SVG tags directly in HTML documents. Requires HTML5 parser.
Method of using SVG transforms, filters, etc on HTML elements using either CSS or the foreignObject element

Method of using a grid concept to lay out content, providing a mechanism for authors to divide available space for layout into columns and rows using a set of predictable sizing behaviors. Includes support for all grid-* properties and the fr unit.
Method of using animation elements to animate SVG images
Method of using fonts defined as SVG shapes. Removed from SVG 2.0 and considered as a deprecated feature with support being removed from browsers.
Method of using images for borders
Method of using multiple images as a background

Method of using small symbols next to each glyph to emphasize a run of text, commonly used in East Asian languages. The text-emphasis shorthand, and its text-emphasis-style and text-emphasis-color longhands, can be used to apply marks to the text. The text-emphasis-position property, which inherits separately, allows setting the emphasis marks' position with respect to the text.
Method that enables applications to take advantage of persistent background processing, including hooks to enable bootstrapping of web applications while offline.
Method to access the vibration mechanism of the hosting device.
Method to get the size and position of an element's bounding box, relative to the viewport.
Method to help web developers measure the performance of their applications by giving them access to high precision timestamps.
Method to help web developers to collect complete timing information related to resources on a document.
Method to programmatically trigger a DOM event.
Method to provide information about the battery status of the hosting device.
Method to provide speech input in a web browser.
Method to provide the current time in sub-millisecond resolution and such that it is not subject to system clock skew or adjustments. Called using performance.now()
Methods for inserting an element or text before or after a given element, or appending or prepending an element or text to a given element's list of children.
Microsoft Developer Network
Microsoft Edge Browser Status
Microsoft Edge Developer UserVoice: No plans
Microsoft Edge UserVoice feature request for :matches()
Microsoft Edge and IE Mobile support this property with the -webkit- prefix, rather than -ms- for interop reasons.
Microsoft Edge does not support IndexedDB inside blob web workers. See issue.

Microsoft Edge feature request on UserVoice (under review)
Microsoft Edge feature suggestion
Microsoft Edge has a bug where min-resolution less than 1dpcmis ignored.

Min-Content tutorial
Minimal Datalist polyfill w/tutorial
Minimal and library dependency-free vanilla JavaScript polyfill
Minimum length attribute for input fields
Missing support for PaymentResponse.prototype.retry() method
Missing: IDBKeyRange includes(), renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()
Missing: Renaming stores/indexes, binary keys, IDBObjectStore getKey(), IDBCursor continuePrimaryKey()
Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by whitelisting allowed sources of script, style, and other resources.
Mitigate cross-site scripting attacks by whitelisting allowed sources of script, style, and other resources. CSP 2 adds hash-source, nonce-source, and five new directives
Modernizing TLS connections in Microsoft Edge and Internet Explorer 11 - Microsoft Windows Blog
Modernizing Transport Security - Google Security Blog
More effective lossless compression algorithm than gzip and deflate.
Most browsers support this spelled as a prefixed :-vendor-any() pseudo-class.
Most mobile devices have a delay in updating the background position after scrolling a page with fixed backgrounds.
Most partial support refers to supporting an older version of the specification or an older syntax.
Motion Path
Moving the scrollbar on an object with pointer-events: none; works in Firefox, but doesn't work in either Chrome or IE.

Mozilla bug #1266283 - Implement CSS4 descendant combinator `>>`

Mozilla: Introduction to CSS Grid Layout
Multi-browser demo
Multi-touch demo
Multimedia format designed to provide a royalty-free, high-quality open video compression format for use with HTML5 video. WebM supports the video codec VP8 and VP9.
Multiple backgrounds
Multiple column layout
Multiple file selection
Mutation Observer
Mutation events
MutationObserver from MDN
Native CSS Feature Detection via the @supports Rule
Navigation Timing API
Negative values do not work in Firefox.
Nested menus are not supported
Network Information API
Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Originally started out from the SPDY protocol, now standardized as HTTP version 2.
Networking protocol for low-latency transport of content over the web. Superseded by HTTP version 2.
New number and Math features in ES6
New properties to affect background images, including background-clip, background-origin and background-size
News and information site
Next version of WebGL. Based on OpenGL ES 3.0.
No events are fired at all in WebKit/Blink browsers during animation (onbegin/onrepeat/onend) see bug
No support for WritableStream.
No support for BYOB ("bring your own buffer") stream readers.
No support for SVGImageElement as Source Image
No support for options parameter, resizeWidth, resizeHeight, resizeQuality or SVGImageElement as Source Image
No support for resizeWidth, resizeHeight, resizeQuality or SVGImageElement as Source Image
No support for the pipeTo or pipeThrough methods
Node.compareDocumentPosition()
Node.innerText
Node.textContent
Non-base64-encoded SVG data URIs need to be uriencoded to work in IE and Firefox as according to the specification.
Non-standard method of scaling content.
Non-standard methods of styling scrollbars.
Not all browsers with support for the Audio API also support media streams (e.g. microphone input). See the getUserMedia/Streams API data for support for that feature.
Not all mobile browsers offer print support; support listed for these is based on browser engine capability.
Not applicable to Firefox platforms that support neither pointer nor touch events.
Not available in Web Workers in Firefox 19.
Not before inline-elements

Not every computer or smartphone could run WebVR appication. For smartphones, you need a gyroscope and for computers must be VR-ready also the needed sotfware (Oculus client or (Steam VR and VivePort)) and drivers must been installed on the computer. In this situations, you've the best experiance to use WebVR applications.
Not shipped with the inital release but later with the 2018 June security update (Patch Tuesday) to Windows 10 RS3 (2017 Fall Creators Update) and newer. More info.
Not supported by IE Mobile 9 and below.
Not supported by Safari for Windows
Not supported in Chrome 47 for iOS & below or other older iOS WebViews using UIWebView instead of WKWebView see details
Not supported in some versions of Android's old WebKit-based WebView.
Not supported means any file can be picked as if the accept attribute was not set, unless otherwise noted.
Not supported on quotes property
Not supported on Android 4.x and below, presumably an OS limitation. Only seems to work in Android 5.x for the Chrome browser.
Not supported on Windows 7.
Not supported on any table parts - See Firefox bug
Not supported on any pseudo-elements besides ::before and ::after for Firefox, Chrome 26+, Opera 16+ and IE10+.

Note that <input type="range"> can never match :out-of-range because the user cannot input such a value, and if the initial value is outside the range, the browser immediately clamps it to the minimum or maximum (as appropriate) bound of the range.
Note that WebGL is part of the Khronos Group, not the W3C.
Note that both the border-style and border-width must be specified (not set to none or 0) for border-images to work.
Note that prefixes apply to the value (e.g. -moz-crisp-edges), not the image-rendering property.
Note that this property is significantly different from and incompatible with Microsoft's older "filter" property.
Notes
Now deprecated method of defining web page files to be cached using a cache manifest file, allowing them to work offline on subsequent visits to the page.
Number input type
OM Scroll-behavior
ON parsing
ORTC is often dubbed WebRTC 1.1. It is possible to make ORTC communicate with WebRTC 1.0 endpoints. See WebRTC 1.0 for support details for that API.
OWASP Clickjacking Defense Cheat Sheet
OWASP article
Object RTC (ORTC) API for WebRTC
Object.observe data binding
Object.values method
Object.values() on MDN Web Docs
Offers appropriate file locations/input based on format type, but does not prevent other files from being selected.
Official code repository
Official site
Official website
Official website FAQ - Which web browsers natively support WebP?
Offline web applications
OffscreenCanvas
OffscreenCanvas allows canvas drawing to occur with no connection to the DOM and can be used inside workers.
Ogg Vorbis audio format
Ogg/Theora video format
Old Firefox versions were missing support for some properties: loop was added in v11, played in v15, playbackRate in v20.
Old version of W3C recommendation containing font-smooth
Old versions of Chrome use non-standard code points for ChaCha20-Poly1305 cipher suites.

Old versions of WebKit-based desktop browsers (Chrome<27, Safari<6) suffer from a bug where if -webkit-text-size-adjust is explicitly set to none, instead of ignoring the property, the browsers will prevent the user from zooming in or out on the webpage.
Older (presto-based) versions of the Opera browser have also supported the same effect using the proprietary -o-ellipsis-lastline; value for text-overflow.
Older iOS versions and Android 4.0.4 claim support, but implementation is too buggy to be useful.
Older versions of Chrome and Opera on Windows have only millisecond precision. The fractional part is always near the very start or the very end of a millisecond. (issue #158234).
Older versions of Chrome and Safari do not support feConvolveMatrix and their lighting implementation is incomplete.
Older versions of IE11 have only partial support of the spec, though it's much better with the latest update.
Older versions of iOS did not support video as a source for the canvas drawImage(), though it does appear to work as of iOS 8 test case
Older webkit browsers also support the unofficial intrinsic value which acts the same as max-content.
On Mac OS X, unless Full Keyboard Access is enabled, <a> elements are not keyboard-focusable, even if they have tabindex="0".
On Windows, files that do not apply are hidden. On OSX they are grayed out and disabled.

On iOS Safari and Chrome for Android, 100vw 100vh are sized to the 'largest possible viewport' where they may be larger than <html> 100% being the 'smallest possible viewport', all during the user's scrolling. On Safari for iPad with the sidebar on, the 'largest possible viewport' may be when the content is scrolled until it fills all the area beneath the blurred sidebar.
On iOS the ended event is not fired when the screen is off or the browser is in the background (meaning that e.g. src cannot be changed).
On mobile devices, the text-size-adjust CSS property allows Web authors to control if and how the text-inflating algorithm is applied to the textual content of the element it is applied to.
On textarea resizing
Online/offline status
Only Firefox (and Opera 12) supports the prefer-online option under SETTINGS
Only WebM video is supported.
Only appears to support the #t=n,n control for selecting a range of video, and possibly track=(name) & id=(name) (not yet tested)
Only available in Chrome and Opera within ServiceWorkers.
Only basic read support.
Only cachable resources can be preloaded. This includes the following as values: script, style, image, video, audio, track, fetch, and font (note font/collection is not supported).
Only fires copy event on a valid selection and only cut and paste in focused editable fields.
Only in Opera Mobile
Only matches the very first character. The spec says that surrounding punctuation should also match.
Only recognized when NOT in strict mode
Only recognizes the deprecated :first-letter pseudo-class, not the ::first-letter pseudo-element.
Only replaces WebkitCSSMatrix and not SVGMatrix
Only select elements containing specified content. For example, a:has(>img) selects all <a> elements that contain an <img> child.
Only supported in IE11 in later versions of Windows 10 (creators update).
Only supported in IE6 and IE7 on elements with a display of "inline" by default. Alternative properties are available to provide complete cross-browser support.
Only supported in strict mode
Only supported on Android & Mac platforms (and only the "auto" value) for now. See commit & related bug.
Only supported on Windows Vista or above (not Windows XP)
Only supports KeyboardEvent.keyLocation from an older draft of the DOM Level 3 Events spec instead.
Only supports Text and URL data types and uses a non-standard method of interacting with the clipboard.
Only supports local when -webkit-overflow-scrolling: touch is _not_ used
Only supports paste event (on focused editable field).
Only supports HTTP2 if servers support protocol negotiation via ALPN
Only supports HTTP2 over TLS (https)
Only supports OS clipboard reading/writing via shortcut keys, not through document.execCommand().
Only supports basic support without locale & options parameters.
Only supports console functions when developer tools are open, otherwise the console object is undefined and any calls will throw errors.
Only supports styling scrollbar colors, no other properties to define the scrollbar's appearance.
Only supports the *-start, and *-end values for margin, border and padding, not the inline/block type values as defined in the spec.
Only supports the old flexbox specification and does not support wrapping.
Only supports the 2012 syntax
Only supports the :-moz-any() pseudo-class.
Only supports the :-webkit-any() pseudo-class, which is deprecated due to handling specificity incorrectly.
Only supports the DOMMatrix version of the interface, not WebKitCSSMatrix (support required by spec for legacy reasons)
Only supports the WebKitCSSMatrix version of the interface, not DOMMatrix
Only supports the allow attribute on iframes
Only supports the downlink, effectiveType & rtt values.
Only supports the type and downlinkMax values.
Only supports the type value.
Only supports the older event-based specification
Only works in Android 2.1 thru 2.3 by using the following meta tag: <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, user-scalable=no">.
Only works in IE11 for Windows 10, not older versions of Windows
Only works on <img> and CSS backgrounds, _not_ <canvas>.
Only works on <img>, not CSS backgrounds or <canvas>.
Only works on ChromeOS
Only works on secure (https) servers
Opacity

OpenType font settings that allows a single font file to behave like multiple fonts: it can contain all the allowed variations in width, weight, slant, optical size, or any other exposed axes of variation as defined by the font designer. Variations can be applied via the font-variation-settings property.
OpenType layout feature tag registry
Opening the image in a new tab in Chrome results in the image shown in the orientation according to the EXIF data.
Opera
Opera (Presto) has classList support on SVG elements, but not on MathML elements.
Opera 12.1 and IE9 incorrectly include scrollbar width for media queries based on window width.
Opera 12.1 uses the older specificaton's :fullscreen-ancestor pseudo-class instead of the the ::backdrop pseudo-element.
Opera Mini
Opera Mini correctly applies style on initial load, but does not correctly update when value is changed.
Opera Mini ignores the blur-radius set, so no blur effect is visible. Text-shadow behavior can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "dropshadow" or "glow" filters.
Opera Mini supports the canvas element, but is unable to play animations or run other more complex applications.
Opera Mobile
Opera Mobile (Classic) has a caching bug when getElementsByClassName is used while document.readyState is "loading"
Opera Mobile and Opera Mini only support the 'orientation' property.
Opera extension providing support
Opera messes background repeat when changing zoom level: known issue in Opera's private bug tracker (CORE-33071)
Opera's support is limited to a CSS profile of MathML. Support was added in Chrome 24, but removed afterwards due to instability.
Optimizing with font load events
Opus
Orientation Sensor
Original Proposal
Original WICG EventListenerOptions repository

Originally a single property for controlling overflowing content in both horizontal & vertical directions, the overflow property is now a shorthand for overflow-x & overflow-y. The latest version of the specification also introduces the clip value that blocks programmatic scrolling.
Originally implemented only in Internet Explorer. Although several other browsers support the property, using transform: scale() is the recommended solution to scale content.
Other
Overflow-wrap
Override the content specified in the src attribute (if present) with HTML content within the attribute.
Overview of objects & properties
PEP: Pointer Events Polyfill
PKI.js - another crypto library for Public Key Infrastructure applications
PNG
PNG alpha transparency
PNG favicons
PWACompat (polyfill) - A library that brings the Web App Manifest to non-compliant browsers
Page Visibility
PageTransitionEvent
Paint API
Parsing and Serialization
Partial in Safari refers to not supporting the hue, saturation, color, and luminosity blend modes.
Partial refers to only supporting the isFinite and isNaN methods.
Partial refers to only supporting the isFinite, isInteger, and isNaN methods.
Partial refers to supporting <integer> but not <length> values.
Partial refers to supporting all new features except the isSafeInteger method.
Partial refers to supporting the same as #1 and the addition of the EPSILON property.
Partial support because only supported in IE 11 on Windows 10 RS3 (2017 Fall Creators Update) and newer, but not in IE 11 on other Windows versions (Windows 7, ...)
Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the dom.fetch.enabled flag.
Partial support can be enabled in Firefox with the dom.serviceWorkers.enabled flag.
Partial support for older Firefox versions refers to the lack of support in OS X & some non-Android Linux platforms.
Partial support in Android 3 & 4 refers to not supporting masking.
Partial support in Android Browser 4.4 refers to the browser lacking the ability to multiply and divide values.
Partial support in Android browser refers to buggy behavior in different scenarios.
Partial support in Android browser versions is due to a serious bug where text-rendering: optimizeLegibility causes custom web fonts to not render.
Partial support in Chrome refers to the browser intentionally ignoring autocomplete="off" when the user uses the browser's autofill functionality. see bug
Partial support in Edge 15 and older refers to a lack of support for SVG data URIs. see bug
Partial support in Edge 15+ refers to support for only the HTTP header format, not the <link rel> format.
Partial support in Edge 17+ refers to support for only the HTML <link rel> format, not the HTTP header format.
Partial support in Edge refers to broken nonce suport which will lead to breakages since sourced script tags with a valid nonce will get blocked.
Partial support in Edge refers to object-fit only supporting <img> (see this comment)
Partial support in Firefox before version 34 only implemented the url() function of the filter property
Partial support in Firefox before version 41 refers to only loading the SVG favicon the first time, but not on subsequent loads.
Partial support in Firefox is detailed in Are we animated yet?
Partial support in Firefox refers to being limited to context menus, not toolbar menus.
Partial support in Firefox refers to ignoring autocomplete="off" for login forms. see bug
Partial support in Firefox refers to lacking support for image symbols
Partial support in Firefox refers to only support for inline SVG mask elements i.e. mask: url(#foo).
Partial support in Firefox refers to only supporting AAC in an MP4 container and only when the operating system already has the codecs installed.
Partial support in Firefox refers to using the non-standard :-moz-placeholder name rather than :placeholder-shown.
Partial support in IE & Edge refers to not supporting scroll-snap-coordinate and scroll-snap-destination.
Partial support in IE 10 & 11 refers to a number of subfeatures not being supported. Edge does not support IndexedDB inside blob web workers. See issue
Partial support in IE refers to significantly buggy behavior (IE11+ does send the input and change events upon selection).
Partial support in IE refers to not supporting the transform-style: preserve-3d property. This prevents nesting 3D transformed elements.
Partial support in IE refers to supporting an older version of the specification.
Partial support in IE refers to using the non-standard :-ms-input-placeholder name rather than :placeholder-shown.
Partial support in IE10 mobile refers to lack of warning when blocking submission.
Partial support in IE10 refers the lack of pointerenter and pointerleave events.
Partial support in IE10 refers to support limited to touch screens.
Partial support in IE11 documented here
Partial support in IE11 refers to being limited to Windows 10.
Partial support in IE11 refers to only working in Windows 8+

Partial support in IE8 is due to being limited to CSS 2.1 selectors and a small subset of CSS 3 selectors (see notes there). Additionally, it will have trouble with selectors including unrecognized tags (for example HTML5 ones).
Partial support in IE9 refers to supporting "vm" instead of "vmin".
Partial support in IE9 refers to the browser crashing when used as a background-position value.
Partial support in IE9+ refers to the fonts only working when set to be "installable". Support for this is tracked here.
Partial support in Internet Explorer 10-11 refers to the browser only supporting the 'sandbox' directive by using the X-Content-Security-Policy header.
Partial support in Microsoft Edge refers to supporting date, week, and month input types, and not time and datetime-local.
Partial support in Opera 11.10 and 11.50 also refers to only having support for linear gradients.
Partial support in Opera 11.10 and 11.50 refers to only having support for linear gradients.
Partial support in Opera Mini refers to not supporting background sizing or background attachments. However Opera Mini 7.5 supports background sizing (including cover and contain values).
Partial support in Opera Mini refers to only supporting the CSS pseudo classes.
Partial support in Presto-based Opera browsers refers to using an older API (window.supportsCSS)
Partial support in Safari & iOS 8 & 9 refers to seriously buggy behavior as well as complete lack of support in WebViews.
Partial support in Safari 3.* refers to not supporting multiple shadows.
Partial support in Safari 6 refers to not supporting background sizing offset from edges syntax.
Partial support in Safari and Older Firefox versions refers to not using premultiplied colors which results in unexpected behavior when using the transparent keyword as advised by the spec.
Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to OSX 10.11+
Partial support in Safari refers to being limited to OSX 10.12+

Partial support in Safari refers to not supporting the none keyword in scroll-snap-points-x, scroll-snap-points-y and scroll-snap-coordinate, and length keywords (top, right, etc.) in scroll-snap-destination and scroll-snap-coordinate.
Partial support in Safari refers to support for object-fit but not object-position.
Partial support in Safari, iOS Safari and Android Browser refers to missing "inset", blur radius value, and multiple shadow support.
Partial support in WebKit/Blink browsers refers to supporting the mask-image and mask-box-image properties, but lacking support for other parts of the spec.
Partial support in iOS Safari 5.0-5.1 refers to the browser recognizing the X-WebKit-CSP header but failing to handle complex cases correctly, often resulting in broken pages.
Partial support in iOS Safari and older Safari versions refers to failing to support tiling or the background-position property.
Partial support in iOS Safari refers to not supporting the week input type, nor the min, max or step attributes
Partial support in iOS refers to the browser using EXIF data by default, though it does not actually support the property.
Partial support in iOS7 is due to buggy behavior of the "vh" unit (see workarounds: 1, 2).
Partial support in older Chrome versions refers to lacking support in Mac OS X.
Partial support in older Chrome versions refers to using an older version of the spec. Support in Safari 6 is limited to Mac OSX 10.8+.
Partial support in older Chrome, Opera and Android refers to browsers not supporting lossless and alpha versions of WebP.
Partial support in older Firefox and Opera Mini/Mobile refers to SVG images being blurry when scaled.
Partial support in older Firefox refers to being limited to certain operating systems.
Partial support in older IE refers to a buggy implementation (see issue).
Partial support in older Safari refers to strict mode still accepting a lot of JS that should be considered invalid.
Partial support in older Safari versions refers to not working in HTML files or CSS background images.
Partial support in older browsers refers to lacking support for binary data.

Partial support in older browsers refers to the websockets implementation using an older version of the protocol and/or the implementation being disabled by default (due to security issues with the older protocol).
Partial support in older iOS Safari refers to buggy behavior.
Partial support indicates that unnecessary code-ranges are downloaded by the browser - see browser test matrix.
Partial support is due to bugs present (see known issues)
Partial support is due to large amount of bugs present (see known issues)
Partial support refers to a bug where long lists of items are unscrollable resulting in unselectable options.
Partial support refers to limitations in certain conditions.
Partial support refers to text-decoration-skip only supporting value objects and ink.

Partial support refers to an older version of the draft specification, and the spec has undergone significant changes since, for example renaming the screen.lockOrientation method to screen.orientation.lock.
Partial support refers to basic support of element.animate()
Partial support refers to basic support of element.animate() and playback control of AnimationPlayer
Partial support refers to being able to use data-* attributes and access them using getAttribute.
Partial support refers to feature only being available for sites opting into the origin trial
Partial support refers to ignoring the off value for password fields. see related blog post
Partial support refers to incorrect support for -webkit-text-emphasis-position. These browsers support over and under as values, but not the added left and right values required by the spec.
Partial support refers to lack of external fragments support
Partial support refers to lack of filter support or buggy result from effects. A CSS Filter Effects specification is in the works that would replace this method.
Partial support refers to lack of notice when form with required fields is attempted to be submitted. See WebKit bug.
Partial support refers to lacking cancelAnimationFrame support.
Partial support refers to lacking placeholder support on textarea elements.
Partial support refers to lacking support for parseFromString on the DOMParser.
Partial support refers to limited supported formats for dataTransfer.setData/getData.
Partial support refers to missing the default styling, as technically the elements are considered "unknown". This is easily taken care of by manually setting the default display value for each tag.
Partial support refers to no support for datalists on non-text fields (e.g. number, range, color).
Partial support refers to no support for the dataTransfer.files or .types objects
Partial support refers to no support for the alias, cell, copy, ew-resize, ns-resize, nesw-resize, nwse-resize or context-menu cursors.
Partial support refers to not displaying a message for invalid patterns
Partial support refers to not returning a Promise, as specified in the latest version of the spec.
Partial support refers to not supporting 'none'.
Partial support refers to not supporting .setDragImage
Partial support refers to not supporting .timeout and .ontimeout
Partial support refers to not supporting ::backdrop, and supporting the old :full-screen syntax rather than the standard :fullscreen.
Partial support refers to not supporting PushEvent.data and PushMessageData
Partial support refers to not supporting blob as responseType
Partial support refers to not supporting border-image-repeat: round
Partial support refers to not supporting border-image-repeat: space
Partial support refers to not supporting json as responseType
Partial support refers to not supporting embedded images (data URIs) inside the SVG.
Partial support refers to not supporting getComputedStyle on pseudo-elements.
Partial support refers to not supporting the "vmax" unit.
Partial support refers to not supporting the ALLOW-FROM option.

Partial support refers to not supporting the break-before, break-after, break-inside properties. WebKit- and Blink-based browsers do have equivalent support for the non-standard -webkit-column-break-* properties to accomplish the same result (but only the auto and always values). Firefox does not support break-* but does support the page-break-* properties to accomplish the same result.
Partial support refers to not supporting the column-fill property.
Partial support refers to not supporting the region-fragment property.
Partial support refers to not supporting the text-decoration-skip property.
Partial support refers to not supporting the text-decoration-style property.
Partial support refers to only acknowledging different media rules on page reload
Partial support refers to only supporting entries(), keys(), values(), and for...of.
Partial support refers to only supporting EOT fonts.
Partial support refers to only supporting SVG fonts.
Partial support refers to only supporting the url() syntax.
Partial support refers to only supporting the now deprecated BlobBuilder to create blobs.
Partial support refers to only the <main> element (added later to the spec) being "unknown", though it can still be used and styled.
Partial support refers to only working in frames/iframes (not other tabs/windows). Also, objects cannot be sent using postMessage.
Partial support refers to requiring the legacy name "word-wrap" (rather than "overflow-wrap") to work.
Partial support refers to requiring the second parameter to be included.
Partial support refers to severe implementation bug that renders the content inaccessible. https://hiddedevries.nl/en/blog/2018-04-21-more-accessible-markup-with-display-contents
Partial support refers to some attributes missing.
Partial support refers to support everything except of Element.scrollIntoView() and not together with pinch viewport.
Partial support refers to support for the older specification's navigator.battery rather than navigator.getBattery() to access the BatteryManager.
Partial support refers to support inside <img> but not as CSS background-image
Partial support refers to supporting date and time input types, but not datetime-local, month or week.
Partial support refers to supporting fixed but not local
Partial support refers to supporting local but not fixed
Partial support refers to supporting a <length> value, but not the each-line or hanging keywords.
Partial support refers to supporting an earlier draft of the spec.
Partial support refers to supporting filter functions, but not the url function.
Partial support refers to supporting mask-image and mask-size
Partial support refers to supporting mask-image, mask-size, mask-position, and the mask shorthand
Partial support refers to supporting only innerHTML and insertAdjacentHTML.
Partial support refers to supporting only innerHTML.
Partial support refers to supporting shapes and the url(#foo) syntax for inline SVG, but not shapes in external SVGs.
Partial support refers to supporting the break-all value, but not the keep-all value.
Partial support refers to supporting the mask-box-image shorthand but not the longhand properties
Partial support refers to supporting the older specification's "matchesSelector" name rather than just "matches".
Partial support refers to supporting the shorthand syntax, but not the individual properties (border-image-source, border-image-slice, etc).
Partial support refers to the doNotTrack field being misnamed, or being attached to an object other than navigator (e.g. window).

Partial support refers to the lack of compassneedscalibration event. Partial support also refers to the lack of devicemotion event support for Chrome 30- and Opera. Opera Mobile 14 lost the ondevicemotion event support. Firefox 3.6, 4 and 5 support the non-standard MozOrientation event.
Partial support refers to these versions of Firefox returning "MozPrintableKey" for all character keys.
Partial support refers to using alternate names:
Partial support refers to working for inline elements but not across column or page breaks.
Partial supports refers to the lack of hardware acceleration.

Partial workaround: regularly probe the storage's value and compare with the last known value on all pages where you want to listen to this event, and track the last submitted value to determine if the modification was triggered locally.
Partially supported in Firefox by enabling "layout.css.contain.enabled" in about:config
Partially supported in Firefox by enabling "layout.css.shape-outside.enabled" in about:config

Proprietary and undocumented CSS property that will contain text to a given amount of lines when used in combination with display: -webkit-box. It will end with ellipsis when text-overflow: ellipsis is included.

Provides one-off and periodic synchronization for Service Workers with an onsync event.
Provides scripted access to the Input Method Editor (IME). An IME is often used to input characters from East Asian languages by typing roman characters and selecting from the resulting suggestions.
Provides the ability to read the screen orientation state, to be informed when this state changes, and to be able to lock the screen orientation to a specific state.

Read-only property that returns the ratio of the (vertical) size of one physical pixel on the current display device to the size of one CSS pixel.

Readonly inputs of type datetime-local, date, month, and week can still be edited by pressing the Up or Down arrow keys on the keyboard while the input is focused.

Reportedly does not work on Android 4.3 browser for Samsung Note II or the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 on Android 4.2.
Reportedly, Android 4.4 WebViews lose the cache after closing the app.
Reportedly, CORS in EventSource is currently supported in Firefox 10+, Opera 12+, Chrome 26+, Safari 7.0+.

Reportedly, using "text/plain" as the format for event.dataTransfer.setData and event.dataTransfer.getData does not work in IE9-11 and causes a JS error. The format needs to be "text", which seems to work in all the mainstream browsers (Chrome, Safari, Firefox, IE9-11, Edge).

Requires the ‘Experimental JavaScript features’ flag to be enabled

Safari
Safari & iOS Safari (both 6 and 7) does not support viewport units (vw, vh, etc) in calc().
Safari & iOS Safari (both 6 and 7) does not support viewport units for border widths, column gaps, transform values, box shadows or in calc().
Safari (>= 5.1) on Windows has a bug in multiple file uploads when used together with FormData to do binary uploads; each file will be reported as 0 bytes. Single file selection, however, works fine.

Safari (OS X and iOS) and Chrome do not support background-size: 100% <height>px; in combination with SVG images, it leaves them at the original size while other browsers stretch the vector image correctly while leaving the height at the specified number of pixels.
Safari 10 and below can return undefined on properties of dataset in some cases. (See bug).

Safari 10 and below uses min/max width/height declarations for actually rendering the size of flex items, but it ignores those values when calculating how many items should be on a single line of a multi-line flex container. Instead, it simply uses the item's flex-basis value, or its width if the flex basis is set to auto. see bug. Fixed in all versions > 10.
Safari 11 does not support CSS transitions on the flex-basis property.
Safari 3.1 has a caching bug. If the class of an element changes it won't be available for getElementsByClassName.
Safari 5 & 6 seem to not provide geolocation data when using a wired connection.
Safari 5-8 is known to render columns less evenly than other browsers
Safari 5.1 and Android browsers do not support the adjacent selector if the adjacent element is a "nav" element.
Safari 5.1 does not support Float64Array
Safari 5.1 requires a color to be defined for the shadow.
Safari 5.1-10+ does not work as expected with min-heightsee testcasesee bug

Safari 5.1.17 has a bug in when using an element with display:table, with padding and width. It seems to force the use of the border-box model instead of the content-box model. Chrome 21.0 however works correctly, making it difficult to resolve with CSS alone.
Safari 6, iOS 6 and Android 2.3 default browser don't work with a 0px value for "blur-radius".
Safari 6.0.x does not use box-sizing on elements with display: table;
Safari 6.1 and earlier did not apply border-radius correctly to image borders: https://stackoverflow.com/q/17202128
Safari 6.2 has the same partial support as Safari 7.1.
Safari 7.0 supports only the event listener on window, and not on document.body
Safari 8 has a bug with bottom-positioned values background-attachment: fixed;
Safari 8+ supports -webkit-text-decoration-skip with values none and skip (other values behave like none or skip)
Safari 9 doesn't properly shorten the first line of text. Applying margin-top: 1em to the letter fixes this problem.
Safari 9 has support for "pinned tab" SVG icons, but this requires an unofficial rel="mask-icon" to be set and only works for all-black icons on Pinned Tabs.
Safari 9, 10, 11, & 12 are reported to still require a prefix for the related backface-visibility property.
Safari CSS Reference: unicode-range
Safari Developer Library
Safari and Chrome give incorrect results for elements that have the nonstandard zoom CSS property applied to them. See WebKit bug #77998.
Safari and iOS Safari 8 (maybe earlier too) have a bug with currentColor in :after/:before pseudo-content
Safari blocks access to keyboard events in fullscreen mode (as a security measure).
Safari browsers support the pattern attribute but will still allow forms to be submitted if the pattern is incorrect. See the form validation data for details.
Safari claims to support certain font-feature-settings it actually does not. This JS module helps to provide accurate support for this.
Safari does not yet support intrinsic and extrinsic sizing with grid properties such as grid-template-rows
Safari does not yet support usage with CSS Grid Layout properties such as grid-template-rows.
Safari doesn't implement the DragEvent interface. It adds a dataTransfer property to MouseEvent instead. See WebKit bug #103423.
Safari doesn't support stacking, meaning only one element can be set to full screen. webkitRequestFullScreen() is ignored for other elements and no error event is dispatched.
Safari has a serious issue with blobs that are of the type application/octet-stream
Safari ignores the off value for username, email and password fields
Safari implementation bug
Safari implementation is incomplete. Does not allow applying web fonts to the initial letter.
Safari on iOS 5.1 does not support min-width on table elements.

Safari on iOS doesn't implement the spec correctly, because alpha is arbitrary instead of relative to true north. Safari instead offers webkitCompassHeading`, which has the opposite sign to alpha and is also relative to magnetic north instead of true north. (see details)
Safari requires background-position: right 0 bottom 0;
Safari support bug
Safari supports the definition in the CSS Pseudo-Elements Module Level 4 instead of one in the List module due to the flux definition in it.
Safari supports a custom implementation https://developer.apple.com/notifications/safari-push-notifications/. WWDC video by apple : https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2013/614/

Safari's implementation does not completely match the spec, in that only URLs are accepted for the image value and only 'x' is accepted as a resolution. See https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=160934.

Same-site cookies ("First-Party-Only" or "First-Party") allow servers to mitigate the risk of CSRF and information leakage attacks by asserting that a particular cookie should only be sent with requests initiated from the same registrable domain.

Scales images with an algorithm that preserves edges and contrast, without smoothing colors or introducing blur. This is intended for images such as pixel art. Official values that accomplish this for the image-rendering property are crisp-edges and pixelated.

Selectors Level 4 § The Mutability Pseudo-classes: :read-only and :read-write

Selectors Level 4 allows the :not() pseudo-class to accept a list of selectors, which the element must not match any of. Selectors Level 3 only allowed :not() to accept a single simple selector. Thus, :not(a):not(.b):not([c]) can instead be written as :not(a, .b, [c])

Some Samsung-based browsers, have a bug with overflowing text when ellipsis is set and if text-rendering is not auto.
Some configurations of Linux and older Windows machines (those without WebGL support) have trouble with 3D transforms and will treat them as if perspective was set as none.
Some modified versions of the Android 4.x browser do have support for date/time fields.
Some old WebKit browsers (like Chrome 24) support -webkit-text-emphasis, but does not support CJK languages and is therefore considered unsupported.
Some older WebKit-based browsers recognize the properties, but do not appear to have actual support
Some scripts, e.g. Lao, Burmese, Syriac, Khmer are reported not to render in Android 4.2 and 4.3.

Special tags that allow mathematical formulas and notations to be written on web pages.

Specifies the focusability of the element and in what order (if any) it should become focused (relative to other elements) when "tabbing" through the document.

Strict Transport Security
String.prototype.contains: In Firefox 18 - 39, the name of this method was contains(). It was renamed to includes() in bug 1102219
String.prototype.includes
String.prototype.padStart(), String.prototype.padEnd()
Subresource Integrity
Subresource Integrity (MDN)
Subresource Integrity enables browsers to verify that file is delivered without unexpected manipulation.
Support Tables
Support can be enabled via about:config
Support can be enabled via about:flags
Support can be enabled via the dom.forms.inputmode flag
Support can be enabled via the experimental-web-platform-features flag
Support can be enabled with the "security.webauth.u2f" flag
Support can be somewhat emulated in older IE versions using the non-standard "gradient" filter.
Support can be somewhat emulated in older versions of IE using the non-standard expression() syntax.
Support for ':matches()' is available behind the "Experimental Web Platform features" flag
Support for :visited styling varies across browsers due to security concerns.
Support for each-line & hanging is available behind the Experimental Web Platform features flag
Support for zoom-in, zoom-out values for the CSS3 cursor property.
Support for ARIA is rather complex and currently is not fully supported in any browser. For detailed information on partial support see the ARIA 1.0 Implementation Report
Support for recommended algorithms in Firefox
Support for relList on link but not anchor elements
Support for the grab & grabbing values for the cursor property. Used to indicate that something can be grabbed (dragged to be moved).
Support for the TrueType (.ttf) and OpenType (.otf) outline font formats in @font-face.
Support in Android WebView is currently disabled due to this issue
Support in Blink-based browsers is expected to be removed in future versions.
Support in IE11 is based an older version of the specification.
Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS files, not HTML or JS files. Max URI length is 32KB.
Support is limited to images and linked resources like CSS or JS, not HTML files. Maximum size limit is 4GB.
Support is limited to using an iframe as a content source with the -ms-flow-into: flow_name; and -ms-flow-from: flow_name; syntax.
Support library
Support listed is for transition properties as well as the transitionend event.
Support refers to the clip-path CSS property on HTML elements specifically. Support for clip-path in SVG is supported in all browsers with basic SVG support.
Support refers to this format's use in the audio element, not other conditions.
Support starting with macOS 10.13 High Sierra
Supported as constant() instead of env()
Supported as the -apple-system value (only on macOS and iOS)
Supported as the BlinkMacSystemFont value (only on macOS)
Supported correctly in strict mode, otherwise supported without block scope
Supported in CSS Grid, but not Flexbox
Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Brotli Content-Encoding' flag
Supported in Chrome and Opera behind the 'Smooth Scrolling' and/or 'Enable experimental web platform features' flag
Supported in Chrome and Opera by enabling "enable-experimental-web-platform-features" in chrome:flags
Supported in Edge when the AV1 Video Extension (Beta) is installed from the Microsoft Store
Supported in Firefox behind the dom.messageChannel.enabled flag. Reported to not work in web workers before version 41.
Supported in Firefox behind the dom.webcomponents.enabled flag.
Supported in Firefox behind the dom.webcomponents.shadowdom.enabled flag.
Supported in Firefox behind the dom.webcrypto.enabled flag.
Supported in Firefox behind the layout.css.touch_action.enabled flag, Firefox for Windows 8 Touch ('Metro') enabled by default.
Supported in Firefox behind the layout.css.will-change.enabled flag
Supported in Firefox by enabling "dom.dialog_element.enabled" in about:config
Supported in Firefox by enabling "media.track.enabled" in about:config
Supported in Firefox under the layout.css.filters.enabled flag.
Supported in Firefox under the layout.css.vertical-text.enabled flag
Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable CSS filter property" flag.
Supported in MS Edge under the "Enable experimental JavaScript features" flag.
Supported in MS Edge with -webkit- prefix only (not with -ms-)
Supported in Opera Mini in SVG images only, not in HTML.
Supported in Safari using the crypto.webkitSubtle prefix.
Supported on th elements, but not thead or tr - See Chrome bug
Supported on th elements, but not thead or tr - See Edge bug
Supported on IE11 Mobile for phones with "Windows Phone 8.1 Update"
Supported only for devices with hardware support
Supported only on Safari for Mac OS Sierra, not El Capitan & older.
Supported only on macOS High Sierra or later
Supported only when packaged in a CAF file and on macOS High Sierra/iOS 11 or later.
Supported somewhat in IE8 and IE9 using the XDomainRequest object (but has limitations)

Supported through the Feature-Policy header and allow attribute on iframes. JS API support is available in Chrome 64+ by enabling the "Experimental Web Platform features" feature flag in under about:flags.
Supported through the X-Content-Security-Policy header
Supported through the X-WebKit-CSP header
Supported using the non-standard value -webkit-optimize-contrast
Supports "Autonomous custom elements" but not "Customized built-in elements"
Supports auto, none, inter-word, inter-character, and distribute with the exact same meaning and behavior as inter-character for legacy reasons.
Supports cut & copy events without a focused editable field, but does not fire paste with document.execCommand('paste')
Supports cut & copy events without a focused editable field, but not paste (presumably for security reasons)

Supports inter-word, but not inter-character or none. Also supports the following unofficial values: distribute , distribute-all-lines, distribute-center-last, inter-cluster, inter-ideograph, newspaper. See MSDN for details.
Supports webkitCancelRequestAnimationFrame rather than webkitCancelAnimationFrame.
Supports window.getSelection() but no selection events
Supports Microsoft's proprietary EventTarget.fireEvent() method.
Supports a "capture" button for any `<input type="file"> field, regardless of the whether the capture attribute is used.

Supports a non-standard version that can only be used in script elements with a type attribute of application/javascript;version=1.7. As other browsers do not support these types of script tags this makes support useless for cross-browser support.
Supports an older draft of the specification with never, always, origin & default values.
Supports notifications via the Push API but not the Web Notifications API.
Supports only Google Daydream on daydream-ready devices and Google Cardboards
Supports only Samsung Galaxy devices with the Samgung Gear VR
Supports only the navigator.connection.type value which doesn't match the latest spec. see details
Supports properties from an older version of the spec.
Supports protocols mailto, mms, nntp, rtsp, and webcal but requires custom protocols to start with web+
Supports scrollIntoView with boolean parameter, but not smooth behavior option
Supports scrollbar styling via CSS pseudo-properties.
Supports selection events, but not window.getSelection()
Supports selector only for input and textarea fields, but not for contenteditable
Supports shapes behind the layout.css.clip-path-shapes.enabled flag
Supports the crisp-edges value, but not pixelated.
Supports the dpi unit, but does not support dppx or dpcm units.
Supports the page-break-* alias from the CSS 2.1 specification, but not the break-* properties from the latest spec.
Supports the pixelated value, but not crisp-edges.
